quotes.topic_title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
quotes.text: And even when I stopped using all the technology, even when I got rid of all the apps, I would sit down on my desk and I'd say, "Oh, you know what? There's that book that I've been meaning what to do some research in," or, "Let me just clean off my desk real quick," or, "You know what? I should take out the trash."
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that distraction persists even without apps or internet, shifting attention to deeper causes.

quotes.topic_title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
quotes.text: And I kept getting distracted because the problem is not our technology. The problem is our inability to deal with discomfort.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing that the root cause of distraction is emotional discomfort, not devices.

quotes.topic_title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
quotes.text: So, what I have adopted for myself and what I'd advise anyone who finds themselves in this situation is to always identify what is that internal trigger, what is that itch that you are looking to escape when you get distracted, because that is the source of 90% of our distractions.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Actionable method: identify the internal trigger/itch behind distraction as the primary lever to address it.

quotes.topic_title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
quotes.text: It's not the pings, dings, and rings. It's the feelings.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Memorable mental model that redirects focus from external notifications to internal emotional drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Internal triggers, not tech, cause distraction
quotes.text: Then you can have tools ready to go. You can have arrows in your quiver ready to take out as soon as you feel that discomfort.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Practical implication: prepare coping tools in advance to respond immediately when discomfort arises.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get very tactical about how to become less distractable and how to get better at focusing on doing the work that you know need to do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets the practical, execution-focused goal of the episode: reducing distraction and improving follow-through on important work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Nir shares at least a dozen tools and tricks that you can put into place today to help you stay focused and avoid getting distracted.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights immediate, implementable tactics rather than abstract theory, signaling a toolkit approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: After this conversation, I've already implemented some of these tactics and they're actually working.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete testimonial that the tactics are actionable and effective in real use.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background

quotes.speaker: Lenny

quotes.topic_title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
quotes.text: So, I wrote this book for me more than anyone else. That's the only reason I write books. It's not because of what I know, but because of what I want to know.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A practical creator mindset: write/learn by targeting your own recurring problem, not by pretending to be the expert.

quotes.topic_title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
quotes.text: But we all basically know common-sense stuff like if you want to get in shape, you have to exercise and eat right, okay?
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Reframes productivity and self-improvement as an execution problem, not an information problem—pushing practitioners to focus on follow-through systems.

quotes.topic_title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
quotes.text: What we don't know is how to get out of our own way, how to stop getting distracted.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core bottleneck as self-sabotage via distraction, guiding practitioners to prioritize distraction-management tactics over more “tips.”

quotes.topic_title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
quotes.text: And what the conventional wisdom out there written by a lot of college professors that are all tenured is stop using technology, stop checking email, get off social media. It's melting your brain, but that's not very helpful, right?
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Challenges the common “quit tech” prescription and sets up a more realistic approach for people whose work depends on digital tools.

quotes.topic_title: Why Nir wrote Indistractable; common myths
quotes.text: Maybe if you have tenure, that's okay, but I can't stop using technology. My career will plummet. I have to use these tools.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A concrete constraint that makes the advice actionable: design focus strategies that work within unavoidable technology use.

quotes.topic_title: Defining distraction: traction vs distraction
quotes.text: Then in fact, the opposite of distraction is not focus. The opposite of distraction is traction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Reframes the problem with a clearer opposite that enables a practical model for choosing actions.

quotes.topic_title: Defining distraction: traction vs distraction
quotes.text: And what separates traction from distraction is one word, and that one word is intent.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Gives a simple decision rule practitioners can use to classify any activity as helpful or harmful.

quotes.topic_title: Defining distraction: traction vs distraction
quotes.text: So, just because it's a work-related task, doesn't mean it's not a distraction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that “productive-looking” tasks (email/Slack/news) are automatically aligned with priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Defining distraction: traction vs distraction
quotes.text: These are things in our outside environment, the usual suspects, the pings, the dings, the rings, all this stuff in our outside environment, which we tend to blame for distraction, but studies find, that's only 10% of the reason we get distracted, 10% of the time it's because of something outside of us. What's the other 90%? Turns out 90% of the time that we get distracted, it's not because of what's happening outside of us, but that most distraction begins from within boredom, loneliness, fatigue, uncertainty, anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Provides a data-backed shift in focus from external interruptions to internal emotional triggers as the primary driver of distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
quotes.text: but studies find, that's only 10% of the reason we get distracted, 10% of the time it's because of something outside of us. What's the other 90%? Turns out 90% of the time that we get distracted, it's not because of what's happening outside of us, but that most distraction begins from within boredom, loneliness, fatigue, uncertainty, anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive data point reframing distraction as primarily driven by internal states rather than notifications.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
quotes.text: So, step number one to becoming indistractable is to master those internal triggers or they will become your master.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A memorable directive that turns focus improvement into managing internal emotional triggers first.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
quotes.text: Step number one, master internal triggers. Step number two, make time for traction. So, this is where we're turning our values into time. We can talk about how to do that. Step number three is hack back the external triggers.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A practical framework that sequences focus work from internal triggers to scheduling traction to reducing external triggers.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
quotes.text: But what about all the non-obvious external triggers? What about stupid meetings that didn't need to be called? What about emails that didn't need to be sent and received? What about our kids? Our kids are wonderful. I know you're a new dad, they're fantastic to have kids, but they can also be a source of distraction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Expands “external triggers” beyond devices to overlooked sources like meetings, email norms, and family interruptions.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework to become indistractable
quotes.text: and then finally prevent distraction with pacts and pacts are this firewall, this last resort against distraction that we can use to keep distraction at bay and it's really about these four steps in concert in this order that anyone can use to become indistractable.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Introduces “pacts” as a last-line-of-defense mechanism and emphasizes using all four steps together in order.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
quotes.text: So, if we use this model, step number one is master the internal triggers.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Introduces a practical diagnostic framework: start by identifying the internal trigger driving distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
quotes.text: And even when I stopped using all the technology, even when I got rid of all the apps, I would sit down on my desk and I'd say, "Oh, you know what? There's that book that I've been meaning what to do some research in," or, "Let me just clean off my desk real quick," or, "You know what? I should take out the trash."
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A concrete example showing distraction persists even without devices, pointing to a deeper cause than technology.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
quotes.text: And I kept getting distracted because the problem is not our technology. The problem is our inability to deal with discomfort.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that shifts focus from external tools to emotional regulation as the core lever.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
quotes.text: So, what I have adopted for myself and what I'd advise anyone who finds themselves in this situation is to always identify what is that internal trigger, what is that itch that you are looking to escape when you get distracted, because that is the source of 90% of our distractions.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Actionable advice plus a memorable quantification that emphasizes diagnosing the “itch” behind distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing Lenny’s distraction: avoiding hard thinking
quotes.text: It's called the 10-minute rule, and this is just one of a dozen different techniques that you can use that I put in the book, but this is one that I use almost every single day.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Names a specific, repeatable technique practitioners can try immediately when they feel the urge to distract themselves.

quotes.topic_title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
quotes.text: Every time that I am tempted to go do something else, which is all the time, what I will do is I will take out a timer, I'll take out my phone and I'll say, "Set a timer for 10 minutes." I'll put the phone down and my job is for those 10 minutes, whenever I'm ready, get back to the task at hand or do what's called surf the urge.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable protocol for interrupting distraction by inserting a 10-minute delay and returning to the task or observing the urge.

quotes.topic_title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
quotes.text: Surfing the urge acknowledges that these emotions are like waves. They crest and then they subside.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A mental model for handling internal triggers by treating urges as temporary sensations rather than permanent states.

quotes.topic_title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
quotes.text: But a much healthier technique is not to tell yourself no. It's to tell yourself not yet.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing that reduces backfire from abstinence by postponing rather than forbidding the distraction.

quotes.topic_title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
quotes.text: My personal mantra whenever I feel this internal trigger is I remind myself this. I say, "This is what it feels like to get better. This is what it feels like to get better."
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A simple self-coaching script practitioners can use in the moment to normalize discomfort and persist through it.

quotes.topic_title: The 10-minute rule and surfing the urge
quotes.text: There's nothing we can do about distraction that our focus is being stolen. It's not being stolen, we're giving it away.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A provocative agency-first framing that shifts responsibility from technology to personal choice and practice.

quotes.topic_title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
quotes.text: You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Defines a crisp mental model: distractions are only identifiable relative to a pre-planned commitment (your calendar).

quotes.topic_title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
quotes.text: What you want to do, and this is step number two, is you're making time for traction by turning your values into time, which means you are going to make a time box schedule because you cannot call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Gives an actionable methodology: translate values into calendar timeboxes to operationalize “traction.”

quotes.topic_title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
quotes.text: If that's not what's written in your calendar, if it's not there, it's a distraction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A strict rule practitioners can apply immediately to reduce rationalizations and impulsive task-switching.

quotes.topic_title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
quotes.text: Values are attributes of the person you want to become.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Provides a memorable definition that anchors weekly planning around identity-based values rather than vague goals.

quotes.topic_title: Timeboxing values: calendar over to-do lists
quotes.text: This is one of the main reasons why to-do lists suck, is because to-do lists have no constraints.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A contrarian critique that motivates switching from unconstrained to-do lists to constrained calendar timeboxing.

quotes.topic_title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
quotes.text: It was like a two- or three-hour block of deep work time and that made a big dent in my ability to have time to focus because people weren't booking me as a PM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete scheduling tactic: reserving large calendar blocks for deep work prevents others from fragmenting your focus time.

quotes.topic_title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
quotes.text: that illustrates a really good point that when the stakes are high enough, I hear people a lot of times saying, "I just can't find the time to focus and I can't get this done and it's impossible these days."
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A reframing that challenges “no time” narratives by tying follow-through to the perceived stakes.

quotes.topic_title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
quotes.text: Okay, let's say that if you don't work out, 8:00 A.M. Monday morning, if you don't work out, you're going to have to pay me $10,000. Are you going to do it? Are you going to work out?
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A vivid example of a “price pact” that uses financial penalties to force prioritization and action.

quotes.topic_title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
quotes.text: Okay, so we've established you can. Now, we're just negotiating the price.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: once capability is proven under high stakes, the real lever is choosing an effective commitment cost.

quotes.topic_title: Pacts and stakes: precommitment and price contracts
quotes.text: Now, the important thing is you have to do this last. If you don't figure out the internal triggers, most importantly, if you don't make time for traction in your schedule, if you don't hack back the external triggers, this fourth step won't work.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A sequencing framework that positions pacts as a last-resort “firewall” after addressing internal triggers, scheduling, and external distractions.

quotes.topic_title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
quotes.text: We need to stop measuring ourselves by how many cute little boxes we check off.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that challenges the common “checklist = productivity” mindset.

quotes.topic_title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
quotes.text: Rather, it's, "Did I do what I said I was going to do for as long as I said I would without distraction?" I'll say it again. "Did I do what I said I was going to do for as long as I said I would without distraction?"
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A practical metric for productivity that replaces task completion with timeboxed, distraction-free execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
quotes.text: The problem with to-do lists is that there is no feedback loop, there's no feedback mechanism.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Explains why to-do lists fail in practice: they don’t generate learning about time/effort required.

quotes.topic_title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
quotes.text: So, this is why you have what's called the planning fallacy with people who use to-do lists, which says that on average, studies have found that tasks take people three times longer to finish than they estimate.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A concrete data point that motivates measuring time and attention rather than optimistic task estimates.

quotes.topic_title: Why to-do lists fail; measure time, not tasks
quotes.text: So, I worked on that presentation, it needs to be 30 slides long, and I worked on it for 30 minutes and I finished two slides. Okay, great. Well now, I know that I need 10 more of those time boxes to finish the entire task.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: A vivid example of using timeboxing as a feedback loop to estimate remaining work accurately.

quotes.topic_title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
quotes.text: What we find is that people who are very deadline motivated, they do finish what they say they're going to do, but of course, the quality is crap.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that deadlines are a reliable productivity tool by highlighting the quality tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
quotes.text: But the reason people don't do this is because they don't understand how important it is, one, to manage those internal triggers.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Introduces a practical starting point—addressing internal triggers—as the root lever for reducing procrastination.

quotes.topic_title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
quotes.text: you're always going to procrastinate because fundamentally, procrastination is an emotion regulation problem. It's not a character flaw.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Reframes procrastination as a skills gap (emotion regulation) rather than a moral failing, pointing to a different solution path.

quotes.topic_title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
quotes.text: And then, the part that people don't do is actually planning out not the task itself, but the time to work on the task without distraction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable method: schedule distraction-free time blocks rather than just listing tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Deadlines, procrastination, and emotion regulation
quotes.text: That's the part that if you can implement that step two that I talked about of making time for traction, that becomes a game changer.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Names a memorable methodology (“making time for traction”) and emphasizes its outsized impact when implemented.

quotes.text: procrastination is an emotion regulation problem
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Reframes procrastination from a time-management issue to managing uncomfortable emotions, guiding where to intervene first.

quotes.topic_title: Motivation: escaping discomfort drives behavior
quotes.text: It's not about the pursuit of pleasure and the avoidance of pain. It's not about carrots and sticks, but in fact, the carrot is the stick, okay?
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Contradicts the common “pleasure principle” model and introduces a memorable mental model for motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Motivation: escaping discomfort drives behavior
quotes.text: It is all about the desire to escape discomfort.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Provides a simple, actionable diagnostic: when you’re stuck or distracted, look for the discomfort you’re trying to avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Motivation: escaping discomfort drives behavior
quotes.text: high performers, they feel the same internal triggers. They also feel lonely. They also feel bored. They also feel stressed. They also feel anxious, but they use that discomfort like a rocket fuel to propel them towards traction.
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.context: Normalizes internal triggers and offers a performance model: the difference is converting discomfort into action rather than escape.

quotes.topic_title: Motivation: escaping discomfort drives behavior
quotes.text: step two would be putting on your calendar, "I'm going to work on writing this newsletter for 30 minutes, 45 minutes, whatever amount of time."
quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
